metadata.sermon_title: Easter Day / Second Sunday of Easter / Third Sunday of Easter
metadata.sermon_start_end: The symbolism of night and darkness pervades the Gospel of John. At the very beginning we hear the proclamation that the light of the incarnate Word of God comes to shine in the darkness (1:5). Repeatedly in this gospel, Jesus teaches that he brings light to the world [...] Open, we pray thee, the eyes of our faith, that we may behold him in all his redeeming work; through the same thy Son Jesus Christ our Lord, who liveth and reigneth with thee, in the unity of the Holy Spirit, one God, now and for ever.

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The preacher treats three distinct pericopes as a thematic unit. While each section focuses on its respective text, the overarching theme of 'revelation vs. imagination' tends to flatten the specificities of the individual passages into a general apologetic for God's otherness.
quotes: The story about Thomas is placed by the evangelist John at the apex of his gospel story for a specific reason.
The book of Job is asking this great question: Is there a living God beyond what we can imagine?
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Focus on the unique 'scandal' of each text. For John 20, explore why the *linen cloths* specifically triggered belief, rather than using them as a general bridge to the 'unthinkable'.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: There is adequate attention to the literary structure (John as 'master dramatist') and the Jewish context of burial. The use of a 'modern translator' for Job shows engagement with the text's linguistic nuances.
quotes: They bound the body tightly... 'as is the burial custom of the Jews'
One respected modern translator puts it this way: 'I will be quiet, comforted that I am dust.'
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Deepen the theological exegesis of the 'whirlwind' in Job to move beyond a general 'God is big' sentiment toward the specific covenantal implications of God answering Job at all.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application regarding the Alabama tornado is concrete but functions more as an illustration of 'misery' than a direct application of the text's specific logic. The application often drifts into generalities about 'modern life' and 'man-made gods'.
quotes: You will come to know it in a hundred other ways, as the death of a friendship, the death of a career...
We can choose a god who suits us in every particular because he is a projection of ourselves.
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Avoid listing general categories of suffering. Apply the specific 'wounds of Christ' to a specific contemporary instance of 'trendy disaffection' or 'skepticism' mentioned in the sermon.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon successfully avoids the 'block' method. The movement from the darkness of the tomb to the darkness of personal grief is fluid. The hearer is drawn into the narrative of the disciples.
quotes: This, in part, is what John’s Gospel means by night.
Thomas stands for all of us here. We haven’t seen the risen Lord.
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Ensure the 'application' doesn't just mirror the text but is 'expounded' by it. The transition from Job's dust to Ash Wednesday is strong but needs more 'proclamatory' force.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: Misery is strongly represented (the 'cold clasp of death'). Redemption is present as an external act of God. Gratitude (the third part) is the weakest, appearing mostly as liturgical response rather than a life-shaping reality for the hearer.
quotes: This is the night in which Sin and Death reign.
He arose from the kingdom of Death and carried away its spoils.
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Develop the 'gratitude' aspect by showing what the 'life in his name' looks like concretely for a person who is 'comforted that they are dust'.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The sermon hints at the 'two ways' by contrasting the 'man-made god' with the 'God who is really God,' but it lacks the sharp Dekkerian edge of being 'lost.' The choice is presented more as an intellectual/existential preference than a matter of life and death.
quotes: We have a real choice. We can choose a god who suits us...
Those traditions will disappear... because they take neither man nor God seriously. [Dekker reference]
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: The preacher should explicitly address the consequence of remaining in the 'night' or choosing the 'domesticated household pet' god. What is lost if the 'Who' is rejected?

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Christ is clearly the telos. The emphasis on the wounds of Christ as the only valid sign of God's presence is a strong Barthian/Dekkerian move. Grace is the foundation of the resurrection victory.
quotes: It was not the sign of his glory that gave proof, but the sign of his sufferings.
The living Son of God had appeared to him personally.
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: In the Job section, make the link to Christ (the 'one Lord') more organic to the text rather than an external dogmatic addition.

8_depth_and_length.findings: The total word count suggests a duration of roughly 21 minutes. However, this is spread over three distinct 'mini-sermons.' Each individual segment lacks the 'breadth' Miskotte demands for true 'depth.'
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Focus on one pericope for the full 20+ minutes to allow the 'specific truth' of that text to be fully exhaled.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon series is theologically sound and maintains a sober, high-church tone. However, it falls short of Dekker’s ideal by fragmenting the focus across multiple Sundays/texts, which prevents the 'depth' required for a single, specific Bible passage to be fully actualized. It leans heavily on the 'misery' of the human condition but lacks a sharp articulation of the 'two ways' (the seriousness of being lost).
strengths: Strong emphasis on the 'extra nos' (outside ourselves) nature of revelation.
Effective use of the 'night' metaphor to bridge biblical narrative and human experience.
Theologically sharp focus on the wounds of Christ as the locus of faith.
weaknesses: Lack of specificity: the 'unique' point of the texts is often subsumed into a general apologetic for God's transcendence.
Insufficient breadth: by splitting the focus, no single text is given the 20-minute 'depth' Dekker requires.
Weak 'Two Ways': the existential stakes of the choice between the living God and idols are not sufficiently pressing.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is a collection of adequate homiletical reflections, but it struggles to be a 'sermon' in Dekker's strict sense because it prioritizes a thematic arc over the radical specificity of a single pericope. It is 'proclamation' in spirit, but 'speech about the gospel' in form.
